Sajida is a health worker and provides health awareness to the ladies of her community. She is also a very good housewife and performs her routine tasks very well. 

Her husband operates an animal sales business. He purchases young animals (goats, sheep, and buffalo), raises them, and sells them at a profit. While they are growing, he sells their milk to earn extra money. 

Sajida is the mother of two sons and two daughters. Three of them study while her youngest daughter is only two years old. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to buy some more animals to sell at a profit. He has been operating his business for the past 10 years and Sajida is very hopeful that a loan investment will help him improving his business further. 

Note: in the photo, the lady with a book (called an Asasah Passbook) is Sajida.

loans.use: to buy animals for selling

loans.name: Sada

texts.en:
Sada is a married woman with three children, one of whom has graduated from school while two still attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. For the past 10 years, Sada has operated a clothing sales business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Sada faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of becoming self-reliant in the future.

Sada plans to use this KES 60,000 loan to purchase bundles of clothes, handbags, shoes and ladies' wear and to renovate her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes, handbags, shoes and ladies' wear and to renovate her business.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 59 years old and married. She has three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Rosemarie has a general store business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 30 years.

Rosemarie requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell.

In the future, Rosemarie would like to save enough money to support and expand the business for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
As a married parent of seven children, Merlinda works hard to support her family.

She has a food stall business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store. Merlinda is borrowing PHP 19,000 through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her food stall business.

Merlinda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell in her stall.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Sonia works hard to support her family.

She has a charcoal sales business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from food vending and farming sugarcane. Sonia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 13 loans from NWTF. 

Sonia is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase more charcoal to sell.

She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda is 51 years old and married. She has six children.

She earns a living by farming sugarcane in the Philippines. Luzminda has been farming sugarcane for 10 years and also earns additional income by running a sari-sari (variety) store and raising pigs.

Luzminda is borrowing PHP 16,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to buy more farm land .

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Arcenia

texts.en:
Arcenia is 56 years old and married. She has six children.

She earns a living by farming sugarcane in the Philippines. Arcenia has been farming sugarcane for 16 years and also earns additional income from running a general store and a pig fattening business.

Arcenia is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to buy a vehicle for her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Am

texts.en:
Am is 32 years old and resides with her husband and children at Siem Reap province. Since 2010, her career has been planting vegetables, and she earns US $3 a day. Her husband has been a policeman in the village since 1997, and his income is US $5 per day. She has two children, 8 and 5 years old. One is studying. 

Each month, she has to spend US $50 on food and US $8 on other expenses. 

Am would like to ask for a loan of US $600 to purchase a motorbike to go to work. 

In the future, she plans to raise more pigs to sell and if she can save more money, she will repair her house to be more comfortable. She will keep part of the profits she gets from her career for her children to study until they finish university.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for traveling to work.

loans.name: Salamat's Group

texts.en:
Salamat is 45 years old, married, and has five children. Her eldest son left education after the eighth year and started working in a factory. The other three are getting their education while her youngest daughter is only three years old and hasn't started her education. 

Salamat herself is a housewife, who performs her household duties very actively and takes care of her children very well. 

Her husband owns a small piece of land and grows different crops on it. He works very hard to get better crops. He also has cows at home which he keeps to sell their milk to his community clients. 

Salamat has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband's milk selling business. With the loan, he will purchase another cow to increase the productivity of milk and make more profits by selling to his clients. 

He has been operating this business for past 15 years and Salamat is very hopeful that an expansion of his business will bring more happiness to her family and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To purchase another cow

loans.name: Sann

texts.en:
From Prey Chor district, Sann, age 27, is married to Mit, age 28. Both work in the farming business as domestic farmers. Sann has two children who attend school. Her husband has been earning a living for many years by climbing the palm trees behind his house. Palm-tree-climbing jobs are very common for poor people who live in the commune. 

Sann has a plot of farming land. She and her husband have earned a better income since her first two children grew up and went to work. 

Sann is looking for a loan to buy two cows because her old cows don’t support her field work.

loans.use: to buy two cows to support her in the field.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school. She owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 5 years, Mwanakombo has operated a clothing sales business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge is competition from other clothes sellers in the area. Mwanakombo dreams of establishing another shop in the future.

Mwanakombo plans to use this KES 20,000 loan to purchase bundles of clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a 37-year-old businessman married to Faith, and they are blessed with two children, 3 and 15 years old. Simon has been buying and selling scrap metal for the past three years with a monthly income of KES 30,000, which he uses to support family members.

Simon is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by the KADET staff. He will use the loan to buy more scrap metal and expand his business. Simon will use the anticipated profit to improve his family's living standard. His hope and dream is to live a comfortable life with his family and be financially stable.

loans.use: To buy more scrap metal.

loans.name: Nathaniel

texts.en:
Nathaniel is 33 years old, married, and has an 8-year-old son. He has been running a hotel (also known as a restaurant) business for 8 years and employs 6 people. He sells breakfast, lunch, and supper to people in his area. Nathaniel plans to use this loan to renovate the hotel and purchase new furniture. He also wants to refurbish the vehicle used by his business. 

This is Nathaniel’s 9th loan with SMEP. He is a good client and repays on time. In the future, he plans to purchase a fleet of Matatus so he can run a mini-bus transport business. He also dreams of developing a plot of land. Nathaniel describes himself as very innovative and dynamic.

loans.use: to renovate the hotel and purchase new furniture.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more raw materials for her furniture business

loans.name: Harison

texts.en:
Harison is 34 years-old, married, and has two children aged four and seven. He has been running a welding business since 2006 and employs two people.  He sells metal and modeling, windows, doors, and other items that involves welding. Harison intends to use the loan to purchase more welding materials used in his business. 

Harison is a good client who repays his loans on time. He hopes to use the profits from his business to expand his small business into a factory that manufactures raw materials into cars and motorcycles. He dreams of being able to buy plots of land so that he can develop residential and commercial buildings.

loans.use: to purchase more welding materials.

loans.name: Sarah Ayuma

texts.en:
Sarah Ayuma is 27 years-old and married with four children.  She has been in the grocery business for ten years.

Her store is in a densely populated area and she receives all types of customers.  She needs to boost her  business by buying more stock.  She also wishes to establish a retail shop from the current kiosk and her future dream is to acquire a wholesale shop.  She would also like to educate her children. Sarah is hardworking and honest.

loans.use: to purchase stock.

loans.name: Seema

texts.en:
Seema is a very active and nice lady. She does embroidery work for her neighboring clients to share the financial burdens of the household with her husband. She learned the art of embroidery from her mother before she was married and now she is earning a reasonable income from her skills. 

She is the mother of eight children. Her two elder daughters also help Seema in her embroidery business while the others are studying in a local school. 

Her husband is also an embroidery expert. They all work very hard to fulfill the orders of their clients by preparing beautiful embroidered dresses. 

Seema has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her family business. With the loan, her husband will purchase embroidery material such as beads, colored thread, and sketches in bulk that will allow them to prepare better quality embroidered dresses and increase their income. 

They have been doing this business for past 25 years and Seema is hopeful that an investment will bring even more profits to them and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To buy embroidering material for her embroidery business

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en:
Yorn has been spending most of her life in rice farming. She is a married woman and mother of three who still live under her care. The other source of  revenue in the family comes from her husband’s job as a domestic porter in the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham Province. The family is able to make a profit about US $6.25 each day to help support their daily expenses. 

Yorn will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies to use on her field. 

Note: Yorn, her husband and her old mother are pictured in front of her house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies to use on her field.

loans.name: Set

texts.en:
Set, 23 years old, resides with her husband and children at Siem Reap province. This couple has worked in construction since 2003. Their income is $7 per day. She has two children, 5 and 3 years old. One is studying. 

Each month, she has to spend US $50 on food, US $3 on utilities and US $15 on other expenses. 

Set would like to ask a loan of US $650 to purchase a motorbike for traveling to work. This loan will facilitate her going to work or somewhere else and reduce the cost of motor taxis. 

In the future, she hopes her children will get a higher education and she will have a good living standard.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for traveling to work.

loans.name: Orzikul

texts.ru: Орзикул проживает в районе Дж. Руми. Ему 51 год. Он женат. Имеет 5 детей. Образование у него среднее. Он более 15 лет занимается растениеводством. На сегодняшний день у него имеется 20 га земли, где на 15 га земли он посеял хлопок, на 3 га пшеницу, а на 2 га земли он выращивает арбуз. По хозяйству ему помогают его дети. Он берет кредит для закупа минеральных удобрений, чтобы посеять и получить хороший урожай.
texts.en: Orzikul lives in the J.Rumy district. He is 51 years old. He is married, with five children. He has received secondary education. He has been working as a farmer for over 15 years. At present he has a land plot of  20 hectares [about 50 acres]: of that, 15 ha is used for growing cotton, 3 ha for wheat, and 2 ha for watermelons. His children help him in this work. He is taking out a loan to buy mineral fertilizers in order to plant and obtain a good harvest.

loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwanaidi is a married woman with six children, three of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past ten years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours. Her major challenge is competition from other food stall operators. Mwanaidi dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future.

With the loan of Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase sacks of potatoes, rice and cooking fat oil. She decided to join Kiva partner Yehu in order to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of potatoes, rice and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Chhung

texts.en:
Chhung is a 28-year-old married man who now lives in Siem Reap Province. He has been married for several years without a baby.

He is a domestic fish trader as well as a rice cultivator. He always buys fresh fish in bulk from local fishermen in the village and then he takes them to sell in the market. His wife supports him in fish-selling business as well. 

He planted a rice crops two months ago, but his crop is not growing well because it needs more fertilizer. To remedy the situation, Chhung would like a loan to buy two sacks of fertilizer for his crop and to buy more fresh fish to continue selling.

loans.use: to buy two sacks of fertilizer for his crop and to buy more fresh fish to sell.

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
Sajida is married by status. Her husband operates a grocery store in the nearby market. Through his store, he sells daily use items such as sugar, salt and other household items. His business is running very well because he offers his products at competitive rates to his clients. 

Sajida is the mother of three children. All of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. Sajida herself is a housewife and stays at home to do her household responsibilities. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will purchase groceries in bulk to fulfill the timely needs of his clients and to improve his business conditions. He has been operating his business for many years and Sajida is confident that he will be able to earn more profit from his business after the loan investment.

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Sajida.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk for his store

loans.name: Maura

texts.en:
This is Maura , 48 years-old and a resident of Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Victor and the mother of seven children.  Two of her children are  working, one is in high school, and the rest are working with her in her food stall. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Maura operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings where all of the family members are at home to take part of the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  Aside from the food stall, she has an apartment for rent. Maura also earns income by selling Liquefied Petroleum Gas. Her stall is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 1133 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products such as meat, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings and an additional gas stove for her food stall. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Maura hopes to be able to expand soon,  just as she hopes to support her children's schooling up to college level, and to pay her house in full. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for products and inventory items needed for her food stall

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 46 years-old and a carpenter.  He is married to Martha who is a mixed crop farmer. They are blessed with four children who are all in school. He has been in the carpentry business for the past three years and earns a monthly income of KES. 10,200 which he uses to support his family members.

He is applying for his third loan from Kiva partner KADET LTD after repaying the previous loans successfully. He will use the loan to buy carpentry tools such as a hammer, saw, nails etc. He hopes to use the anticipated profits to add to the education kitty for his children. 

His future hope is to own a carpentry workshop and to create a source of employment for the people in his community.

loans.use: to buy carpentry tools such as a hammer, saw, nails, etc.

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong, age 46, sells second-hand clothes at the Baray market. From that she is able to earn $2 a day to support her family. 

She doesn’t have a life partner as her husband passed away of illness when her children were very small. Now her children are grown and can support the family by working in a variety of jobs. 

Recently Hong sold nearly all her inventory to her buyers and she wants to replenish her stock but she lacks capital. She is therefore asking for a loan in order to buy more used clothes to resell.

loans.use: to buy more used clothes to resell.

loans.name: Lorielyn

texts.en:
Lorielyn is 34 years-old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Lorielyn has a pigpen that raises pigs to sell.  She has had this business for eight years. She requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy feed for the pigs.

Lorielyn has been a member of Kiva partner HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Lorielyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy feed for pigs.

loans.name: Felibert

texts.en:
Felibert is 32 years-old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with three children. 

Felibert has a pigpen that raises pigs to sell. He has had this business for 15 years. He requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy animal feed for the sow pig.

Felibert has been a member of Kiva partner HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Felibert hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy animal feed for the sow pig.

loans.name: Daniela

texts.en: 58-year-old Daniela is a farmer from the town of Surallah, South Cotabato. She grows rice and corn to sell. Daniela is a widow. She works hard to provide for the needs of her children. She requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm materials. Daniela hopes to have an abundant harvest. She also hopes to have her own capital someday.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm materials.

loans.name: Ana Fe

texts.en:
Ana Fe is 49 years-old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Ana Fe has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, biscuits and beverages.  She has had this business for eight years. She requested a loan of PHP 16,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and  beverages to sell.

Ana Fe has been a member of HSPFI since 2009.  In the future, Ana Fe hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and  beverages to sell.

loans.name: Lun

texts.en:
Lun is a 51-year-old woman, married to Soem, age 47. They live in the Baray district. This couple earns a living by planting various crops on their own farm land. They have five children. Two of their children are working while the other three are still young and attend school. 

Lun will be using the loan to purchase rice seed and potato seed for planting.

loans.use: to purchase rice seed and potato seed for planting.

loans.name: Shameem's Group

texts.en:
Shameem is 40 years old and married. Her husband operates a rickshaw through which he provides transport services to the passengers. Shameem is a caring lady who stays at home to carry out her responsibilities as a housewife. Shameem is the mother of three sons and two daughters. She couldn’t educate her children due to financial constraints. Her two elder sons do jobs and the others stay at home. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy a new rickshaw that will allow him to provide better quality transport services to his passengers. He will rent his old rickshaw, which will earn him extra income every month. He has been operating his transport business for the past 20 years and Shameem is hopeful that her family’s financial condition will be improved as a result of the loan. 

Shameem is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. With her previous loan, she has established good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Shameem.

loans.use: To buy a new rickshaw

loans.name: Ma. Anie

texts.en:
Ma. Anie is 55 years-old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with five children. 

Ma. Anie has a shop that sells t-shirts, blouses and underwear from NATASHA & AVON. She has had this business for 15 years. She requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy additional t-shirts & blouses to sell.

Ma. Anie has been a member of Kiva partner HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Ma. Anie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional t-shirts & blouses to sell.

loans.name: Sinourn

texts.en:
Sinourn, age 30, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is engaged in a business of selling fruits, earning an income of $5 per day to help cover the family expenses. She also raises cows at home to generate more income. 

Sinourn is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike to transport fruits to sell in the city. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to transport fruits to resell.

loans.name: Zaitun

texts.en:
Zaitun is a married woman with five children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past four years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Her greatest monthly expense is competition from other food stall operators. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers' needs.

With the KSHS 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and rice for her food stall. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and rice for her food stall.

loans.name: Hoeurn

texts.en:
Hoeurn (pictured here) is 33 years old and her husband, Vuth, is 39 years old. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1997 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. 
 
Hoeurn sells vegetable. She buys papaya, eggplant and yam and transports them to sell in the market located at another site along the Mekong River. Her husband is a construction worker. She is asking for a loan of $400 to build new walls of her house because they are old and broken.

loans.use: To build new walls for her house.

loans.name: Sultanbek's Group

texts.en:
Sultanbek, 54, is a member of this group. Together with his wife, he brings up four children: two daughters and two sons. The first daughter studies at university, the older son works for the police and the other children are at school. In order to earn money, Sultanbek works as a driver. He also makes additional money by reselling livestock.  The profits gained from the business helped him to give the children a good education. This year Sultanbek’s younger son graduates from school and Sultanbek needs some additional financial funds to pay for his son’s tuition at the Police Academy. For this purpose, he applied for the loan. He hopes that the loan will help him to realize the plans. Sultanbek will be thankful for all the lenders who support his group.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to pay for his son's tuition at Police Academy

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 31 years old and married with two children.  He runs a bodaboda (motorbike) transport business to earn a living.  Apart from the motorbike transport business, he supplies cakes to generate more income.  John was previously earning a living from his small kiosk.
  
John joined Empathy group in Faulu Kenya so that he could easily access business loans because the members of the group guarantee each other's loans.  He has requested 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch (pictured above) is 53 years old and her husband, Mork, is 56 years old. They live in a village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have one son and two daughters. One is married and lives outside the family home and the other two have full-time employment. Touch and her husband are farmers. They grow sesame and gourds and also raise a cow at home. Touch is asking for a loan of $500 US to purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Elizabeth has a shop that sells canned goods, beverages, biscuits & candies. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan for PHP 11,000 to buy canned goods, beverages, breads & biscuits.

Elizabeth has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Elizabeth hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages, breads & biscuits

loans.name: Dionisa

texts.en: Dionisa is 63 years old and married with seven children. She is a farmer and fruit vendor. Dionisa grows rice crops to sell. She grows some of the fruit she sells at her farm and she buys some from other farmers. Dionisa plans to use her loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes to earn more and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Shapagat's Group

texts.en:
Shapagat, 49, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of the village of Tup, a place where vulnerable groups are concentrated. Shapagat believes that only entrepreneurship can pull the people out of poverty and provide them with employment to make a living. Local training by NGOs focuses on promoting awareness of how to work, get a license and improve the local community. Shapagat founded the business of cattle breeding with an initial capital of 20,000 soms saved out of her husband’s income from driving a cab. Although the business has been running for only three years, the family has saved for the reconstruction of the house. Shapagat’s purpose for the loan is to purchase two head of livestock. She believes Kiva lenders’ assistance will help her both financially and mentally. Unlike many of her acquaintances, Shapagat believes in the possibility of earning money through labor in Kyrgyzstan, without having to go to Russia and risk her life and health.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina is 24 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. Gina provides motorela or habal-habal services with her husband as the driver. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos to buy tools and pay for the utilities needed for the maintenance of the service. Gina has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Gina hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for the utilities needed for the maintenance of the service.

loans.name: Dockers Group

texts.en:
Fatuma, who is in her late 20s, is married with two children, both of whom attend school. She has been selling bricks for 6 years. She works from 3 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Fatuma's 7th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to open a shop containing cosmetics and undergarments in the Shinyanga District (almost 300 kilometers from Dar es salam). She also bought and sold bricks. Fatuma has repaid all her loans successfully and wishes for a new loan to buy and sell more bricks. Her dream is to one day own a nice house and a business car like a pickup.

Fatuma will share this loan with her loan group "Dockers", which consists of 15 members, who will hold each other accountable in repaying their loans.

loans.use: To buy and sell more bricks.

loans.name: Shakila's Group

texts.en:
Shakila is 41 years old and married. Her husband is a driver by profession and provides transportation. The eldest child sells crockery such as dinner sets, glasses, etc. The youngest child is only eight years old and has started his education recently. 

Shakila has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her son in his business. With the loan, he will buy different kinds of crockery such as plastic and glass, to sell through his shop. He has been doing this business for the past three years and Shakila is hopeful that an investment in her son’s business will bring good changes to her family life by increasing his monthly income. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. With her previous loan, she established good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Shakila.

loans.use: To buy crockery to sell

loans.name: Anarkan's Group

texts.en:
Anarkan, 52, is the leader of this group. She is a widow and resides in the small-populated village of Tup. The children are grown and have their own families. Anarkan has devoted her entire life to raising her kids and being a good housewife. However, the situation changed three years ago when she lost her husband who was the only breadwinner in the family. Since Anarkan had never worked before, she faced the challenge of finding a job to make a living. After long and thorough thoughts, Anarkan decided to sell her apartment and invest the revenue in the purchase of a smaller place to live and in opening a cattle-breeding business. The start-up capital was 30,000 soms and her monthly income is 2,000 soms. Anarkan believes in the further potential of cattle breeding and wants to broaden the business by purchasing two heads of cattle for fattening and reselling. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Sheryl

texts.en:
Sheryl is a married woman with one infant-aged child. She is 25 years old. She has a retail shop where she sells a variety of products in the community. Sheryl has had this business for three years.

Sheryl is requesting a loan of PHP 9,000 to buy soft drinks, canned goods and other daily needs.

In the future, Sheryl hopes that she can maintain and improve her store so that she can provide the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, canned goods and other daily needs

loans.name: Jurinda

texts.en:
This is Jurinda, 36, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Jaime, a driver, and mother to their children. The entire family manages the household while operating the business. Jurinda works hard to continually provide income for the family's everyday expenses.

Jurinda operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Jurinda earns an income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by individual item. She also has a piggery, where she takes care of hogs and sells them. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. Jurinda earns a minimum of PHP 493 in daily sales.

To help her continue operating her business, Jurinda is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her inventory and to buy pig feed. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Jurinda hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to have her own house and lot in a prominent subdivision in a nice location. She would also like to support her children's schooling up to college level. Jurinda faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her inventory and to buy pig feed

loans.name: Saory

texts.en:
Saory, age 57, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a teacher at a public school, earning an income of $2.3 per day to help cover the family expenses. She also raises chickens at home to generate more income for her family. The family is also assisted by one of her daughters, who is a tailor at a garment factory, earning an income of $3 per day. 

Saory is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase equipment to refine rice wine to sell. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy equipment to refine rice wine to sell.

loans.name: Migombani Group

texts.en: Vicent, who is in his mid 30s, is married with three children who go to school. He has had a general store for six years now. He works from 6:30 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. daily and is able to make a small monthly profit. This will be his fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used his previous loans to expand the general store and for household expenses. He has paid back all his loans successfully and wants a loan to further expand the general store. His dream is to one day own a shop for motor spare parts. He will share this loan with his loan group, Migombani, which has a total of 18 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to increase the shop inventory.

loans.name: Svetlana's Group

texts.en:
Svetlana, 49, is the leader of this group. She is married and has four daughters, the youngest 10 years old. Svetlana has been a farmer in her home village of Tyup for five years. Farming is a seasonal occupation for her; she also works in a local cement producing plant. Svetlana’s daughters made a big contribution of start-up capital for her business, which allowed Svetlana to purchase supplies such as potato seeds. The income from sales of her agricultural products has helped finance her daughter's wedding ceremony. Svetlana has hired field workers for help. Her other major costs include fuel and fertilizers. Svetlana believes that the requested loan will cover these costs. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel and fertilizers

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Sophea, age 26, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a rice field farmer, earning an income of $1 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband, who is a construction worker, earning an income of $3 per day. 

Sophea is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is 36 years old and married.  She lives in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato with her family. Emma has been engaged in farming for more than 10 years. She grows rice and vegetables. Emma rents a stall at the market to sell her harvest.

Emma has requested a loan so she can fund her farm. She plans to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs. Emma hopes to have a prosperous business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Im, age 63, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a rice farmer, earning an income of $1 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

The family is also assisted by one of her children, who is a garment factory worker, earning an income of $5 per day. 

Im is requesting a loan of $1,200 to pay for her son’s administration fee to work in South Korea. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to pay for her son's administration fee to work in South Korea.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is 43 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children.
 
Elsa has a retail shop that sells green and yellow bananas and coconuts for drying into copra. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy bananas and coconuts to sell.

Elsa has been a member of HSPFI since 2007.  In the future, Elsa hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy bananas and coconuts to sell

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen, age 32, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia. He sells coconuts, palm sugar, and palm juice, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by his wife who sells chickens, earning an income of $1 per day. 

Sen is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike to transport coconuts to resell. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to transport coconuts.

loans.name: Mesalimu

texts.en:
Mesalimu is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house, which has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 5 years, she has operated a business selling khangas, a traditional form of dress for women.  She sells to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other khanga sellers. She dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of khangas for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of khangas for sale.

loans.name: Chanly

texts.en:
Chanly, age 29, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She weaves traditional silk, earning an income of $5 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who is employed at a garment factory, earning an income of $6 per day. 

Chanly is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for family use. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for family use.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 39 years old and married.  She is blessed with two children, aged 6 and 10, who attend school.  To earn a living, she sells second-hand clothes.  She has been running this business for three years.  She also sells soap to earn extra income.

Mary has benefited from Faulu Kenya because she has improved her business. In five years, she hopes to grow her business into wholesale.  She has requested 8,000 Kenyan shillings to buy second-hand clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Shaigul's Group

texts.en:
Shaigul, 55, is a leader of this group. In recent years, Shaigul's only income has come from the annual harvest, but she has been dreaming of trying something new. Ten years ago, together with her husband, who has also been a farmer for his entire life, Shaigul sold a rich harvest and obtained a couple of young calves. Shaigul says that the fixed costs of feeding and fattening livestock are not very high, so she can generate more profit. Shaigul is a mother of four and can proudly boast of raising good kids and giving them an education. Since her monthly income is only 1,400 soms, Shaigul was forced to think of additional ways of broadening the business. When she found out about Kiva, she said, “Such projects could improve the lives of many entrepreneurs like me.”

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Lodivina

texts.en:
Lodivina is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with seven children. 

Lodivina has a shop that sells canned goods, breads, biscuits, and beverages. She has had this business for six years. She has requested a loan for PHP 9,000 to buy canned goods, biscuits, and breads for her shop.

Lodivina has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. She hopes to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, biscuits, and breads for her shop.

loans.name: Someoun

texts.en:
Someoun, age 34, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer, earning an income of $0.8 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who is motor-taxi driver, earning an income of $3 per day. 

Someoun is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike for family use. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for family use.

loans.name: Ramir

texts.en:
Ramir is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with three children. 

Ramir provides motorela or habal-habal (transportation) services. He has had this business for eight years. He has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy tools and pay for the utilities needed for the maintenance of the service.

Ramir has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Ramir hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for the utilities needed for the maintenance of his motorcycle service.

loans.name: Phon

texts.en:
Phon is a villager who lives in the province of Siem Reap. He is a local policeman. He has been working in this job since 2006 and has a formal salary each month. 

His wife is a local rice farmer who also breeds a few domestic animals, and she is able to make an income of approximately of $1.5 each day to share responsibility with Phon for daily expenses. 

Phon would like to seek a $600 loan to support his wife by paying for plowing costs and planting potato seeds.

loans.use: to support his wife by paying for plowing costs and planting potato seeds.

loans.name: Eangsim

texts.en:
Eangsim, age 43, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a tailor, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who is a farmer, earning an income of $3 per day. 

Eangsim is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a hand tractor to help plow the rice field. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a hand tractor to help plow the rice field.

loans.name: Arline

texts.en:
Arline is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with six children. 

Arline has a retail shop that makes and sells brooms. She has had this business for two years. She has requested a loan for PHP 9,000 to buy raw materials needed for the making of her brooms.

Arline is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Arline hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for the making of brooms.

loans.name: Sorom

texts.en:
Sorom, age 36, is married and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer, earning an income of $2 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband, who is employed at a hotel in the city, earning an income of $3 per day. 

Sorom is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a tuk-tuk for her husband to start a new motorcycle transport business. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a tuk tuk for her husband to start a new business.

loans.name: Wangnignigbe Ste Rita Group

texts.fr: WANGNIGNIGBE STE RITA est un groupe constitué de quatre personnes et dont la présidente (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) se nomme Christine Ayaba. Les membres du groupe vivent dans le même quartier au Bénin. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupe sollicite pour la quatrième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Christine Ayaba est née en 1949 dans une ville du Bénin et est mariée à  un certain Adolphe. Le couple à cinq enfants, tous scolarisés dont un reste encore à leur charge. Christine Ayaba a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de son enfant, Christine Ayaba mène comme activité la vente des céréales (maïs, riz, haricot) et du charbon de bois à son domicile. Christine Ayaba exerce cette activité depuis près de dix ans, ce qui lui permet d’assurer les diverses charges de sa famille. Christine Ayaba s’approvisionne dans l’un des plus grands marchés du Bénin. Ce quatrième prêt permettra certainement à Christine Ayaba et aux autres membres du groupe WANGNIGNIGBE STE RITA, de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en:
Wangnignigbe Ste Rita is a group made up of four people, whose president (with her hand raised in the photo) is called Christine Ayaba. The group members live in the same quarter in Benin. In order to boost their working capital, they are seeking a fourth credit from ALIDé. Christine Ayaba was born in 1949 in a town in Benin and is married to a man called Adolphe with whom she has five children, who all attend school. They have another child in their care. Christine Ayaba attended school up to secondary level. 
In order to meet her family's needs, Christine Ayaba sells cereals (corn, rice and beans) and charcoal from her home. She has worked in this field for nearly ten years, and the business that she generates enables her to see to her family's various needs. She sources her goods from one of the main markets in Benin.  This fourth loan will enable Christine Ayaba and the other members of the Wangnignigbe Ste Rita group to boost their business levels and to grow their customer base and revenues.

loans.use: to purchase cereals (rice, corn and beans) and charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy additional yellow and green bananas to sell.

loans.name: Gulkair's Group

texts.en:
Gulkair, 42, is the leader of this group. Since her last years of high school, one of Gulkair’s big passions has been baking. “I’ve always loved to bake,” she said.  "Whenever I had a chance, I’d bake something unique for my children.” 

The revenue from the bakery that she opened by her house initially seemed to be enough; however, Gulkair soon realized that she needs an additional source of income. It wasn’t hard to decide what activity it would be: like any resident of Tup village, Gulkair could become a farmer. Ten years ago, Gulkair started cultivating her small but rich piece of land. The fertilizers, fuel, and seeds required the initial capital of 16 500 soms. Gulkair is still cultivating land every spring and gathering rich crops in the fall. This time she plans to plant more vegetables; therefore, she needs more fertilizers. It is with this purpose that she addresses the Kiva lenders. She hopes her efforts will be rewarded with rich harvest.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy rice and beans.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase produce like maize grain, millet, and cassava for milling.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages, rice, and breads.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife is married with one child. Marife is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Marife is a farmer and raises crops to earn a living. She has been doing this for six years. She has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers for her crops.

Marife has been a member of PMPC just this year.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick, a 31-year-old man, is married and has two children.  He is a hardworking businessman who supplies milk.  He started the business five years ago and he has employed two people.  Besides this, he does farming to supplement his income.  He is really grateful to Faulu Kenya because he was able to boost his farming by adding cows on his farm with his previous loan.

Fredrick has requested 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more milk and a refrigerator for milk preservation.  His dream is to purchase a piece of land in the future.

loans.use: To buy milk and a refrigerator

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 50 years old and married with eight children. Her husband works as a farmer and driver. Erlinda is also a farmer. She helps her husband till their land where they grow corn. Erlinda also raises pigs in their backyard.

Erlinda has requested a loan and plans to use it to purchase corn seed, fertilizers and feed. Erlinda hopes to earn more and be able to save for her children's education. She also wants to set aside a budget for emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase corn seed, fertilizers and feed

loans.name: Nooruzkan's Group

texts.en:
Nooruzkan, 56, is the leader of this group. While residing in a small town of Toktogul, she is married and has two grown children. For 10 years, she’s been busy selling foodstuffs and liquor, which she started with an initial capital of 30,000 soms. Since then, she has increased the commodity turnover and made significant contributions to the family budget. Her husband is a farmer and is happy with this business, too. The entrepreneur has been earning 8,000 soms monthly. Nooruzkan’s purpose for the loan is to purchase more foodstuffs and a variety of drinks in order to increase the range of products that she sells. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase foodtuffs and a variety of drinks

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is married with five children. Arlene is 52 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Arlene is a farmer and raises crops to earn a living. She has been doing this for 40 years. She has requested a loan to purchase materials for her house renovation.

Arlene has been a member of PMPC for four years.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her house renovation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To restock her business with more tomatoes, onions, green pepper, Irish potatoes and so on.

loans.name: Yelian Ste Rita Group

texts.fr: Le groupe YELIAN STE RITA est formé de trois  personnes qui résident toutes dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Marcelline , est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la troisième fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. Marcelline est née le 05 Août 1960 au Bénin  et est mariée à un certain Athanase. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Marcelline et sa famille habitent ensemble. Marcelline n’a pas été à l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de sa famille, Marcelline mène comme activité depuis huit ans, la vente de charbon de bois dans son quartier. Marcelline achète ses produits dans une ville du Bénin. La clientèle de Marcelline devient de plus en plus grande, et Marcelline désire rehausser un peu plus le niveau de son activité afin de mieux répondre à leurs exigences. Pour ce faire, et ne disposant pas suffisamment de moyens financiers pouvant lui permettre de réaliser son rêve, Marcelline et son groupe YELIAN STE RITA se sont rapprochés de AILDé, en vue d’un autre crédit.
texts.en:
The YELIAN STE RITA group consists of three people who all live in the same area in Benin. The representative of this group, Marcelline, is seen in the photo with her hand raised. This is the group’s third time seeking financial support from ALIDé to bolster their activity. 

Marcelline was born August 5, 1960 in Benin and is married to a man named Athanase. They have two dependent children who go to school. The whole family live together. Marcelline herself never attended school. In order to help provide for herself and her family, she started selling charcoal in her neighborhood eight years ago. She buys her stock in a city of Benin. 

With the steady growth of her customer base, she seeks to bolster her activity to better serve her clientele. Lacking the financial resources to achieve her goals, Marcelline, together with the other group members, turned to ALIDé to obtain another loan

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Gulbara's Group

texts.en:
Gulbara, 47, is the leader of this group. She is married and has five children, three of whom are high school age. Ten years ago, she spent a month of her husband's salary to open a business. Instead of purchasing land for cultivation or investing in cattle, Gulbara got involved in trading vegetables. She purchases wholesale fresh vegetables delivered from the south of the country and retails them in a local food market. She remembers the times when she had to retail the small assortment of goods for only 3,000 soms. Thanks to her persistence and optimism, she managed to develop the business and raise its level to 10,000 soms monthly. The purpose of Gulbara’s loan is to purchase more goods to broaden the assortment and attract more customers.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables for trade

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Fely is married with three children. She is 42 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Fely is a farmer and grows crops and vegetables to earn a living. She has been doing this for 19 years. She has requested a loan to purchase farm supplies and equipment.

Fely has been a member of PMPC for two years.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en:
Hazel is a farmer working in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato. She is still single. Hazel tills her own land where she grows rice and corn crops. She works hard to support her family financially. She also wants to save for her future family.

Hazel has requested a loan to purchase three sacks of seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for her business to grow.

loans.use: to purchase three sacks of seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Taitus

texts.en:
Taitus, a 27-year-old, is married and has three children.   He owns rental houses, which earn him a living.  He has been operating the business for nine years.  In addition, he does farming. Through Faulu Kenya, he has managed to save his money and service his loans. This has helped him to improve his business. 

Taitus hopes to build more rental houses for more income generation in the future.  He has requested 30,000 Kenyan shillings to renovate his rental houses.

loans.use: To renovate his rental houses

loans.name: Khalila

texts.ru:
Халила родилась в селе Мургаб (Республика Таджикистан). 
Замужем  и является матерью пятерых детей - три дочери и два сына, младший из которых проживает вместе с Халилой и помогает по хозяйству. 
Халила родилась в многодетной простой (7 детей) семье инженера. Она была средней дочерью и большую часть времени посвящала домашним хлопотам. Старшие сестры рано вышли замуж, и ей пришлось присматривать за младшими сестрами и братьями. По окончании школы Халила поступила в Кооперативный техникум по специальности бухгалтер, где познакомилась со своим будущим мужем и в возрасте 19 лет вышла замуж. Вначале они проживали в общежитии, так как муж Халилы тоже из многодетной семьи и своего дома молодожены не приобрели. Два года спустя у них рождается первенец. Халила устроилась на работу в местную  организацию Райпотребобщество и проработала там 12 лет. Год спустя она рожает еще одну дочь. А в 1986 году и 1987 году у семьи Турдуевых появляются на свет еще две девочки. В 1993 году в связи с экономическими трудностями в семье они пререзжают в село Панфиловка (Чуйская область). Два года прожив в с. Панфиловка она рожает еще одного сына.   Халила с мужем устраиваются в местном колхозе на работу  и получают участок земли под жилой дом, который они постепенно достроили. С распадом колхоза, они стали заниматься земледелием на арендованной земле. В 1999 году Халила с мужем устраиваются в ДЭП-42, она в качестве ведущего специалиста, а он в качестве водителя. В 2010 году они покупают дом в селе Вознесеновка (Чуйская область).
Со временем, три дочери вышли замуж и отделились от родителей. Для этого Халиле пришлось продать часть скота. В данное время Халила с мужем по-прежнему работают в ДЭП – 42, разводят скот и занимаются земледелием на арендованной земле. 
Сейчас в хозяйстве Халилы имеется одна корова и телочка. Для увеличения поголовья скота, Халила обратилась в компанию Бай-Тушум и Партнеры за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS). 
Прибыль от кредита она планирует потратить на оплату контракта на обучение сына и дальнейшее расширение бизнеса.  
ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" предоставляет кредиты по линии Кива для социально-уязвимых слоев населения. ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" является одной из лидирующих Микрофинансовых организаций Кыргызстана. "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" – это надежный финансовый партнер, осуществляющий вклад в развитие экономики Кыргызской Республики путем предоставления доступных микрофинансовых услуг в сельской местности и городах, способствующих созданию рабочих мест и отвечающий интересам своих клиентов и инвесторов.
texts.en:
Khalila was born in the village of Murgab (Republic of Tajikistan). She is married and the mother of five children: three daughters and two sons, the youngest of whom lives together with Khalila and helps her with her work.

Khalila was born in an ordinary engineer’s family with seven children. She was a middle child and spent a lot of time on household tasks. Her older sisters got married early, and she needed to take care of her younger sisters and brothers. After finishing high school, Khalila was admitted to a degree program in accounting at junior college, which is where she met her future husband. She got married at the age of 19. The spouses first lived in communal housing since Khalila’s husband also comes from a large family, and the newlyweds did not have a home of their own. Two years later their first child was born. Khalila found a job with the local produce distribution society, where she would remain working  for 12 years. A year later she gave birth to her second child, a daughter. In 1986 and 1987, two more daughters came into the world. In 1993, due to economic difficulties,  the family moved to the village of Panfilovka (the district of Chuisk).  Two years into their life in Panfilovka, Khalla gave birth to another son. Khalila and her husband found work at the local collective farm and were allotted a land plot, on which they eventually had a house built. When the collective farm ceased functioning, they started working as farmers on leased land. In 1999, Khalila and her husband found jobs with the Roadway Management Office  #42: she is a senior specialist, and he as a driver. In 2010, they bought a house in the village of Voznesenovka (the district of Chuisk).

With time, their three daughters got married and settled independently. Because this, Khalila had to buy part of her cattel. At present, Khalila and her husband still work for Roadway Management Office  #42 and also raise cattle and grow crops on the land they lease. At present Khalila has one cow and one heifer. In order to obtain more cattle, Khalila approached Bai Tushum and Partners with a request of a loan of 50,000 KGS.
She plans to use the resulting income to cover the costs of her son’s education and to expand her business further.

The microfinance institution Bai Tushum & Partners offers loans to socially vulnerable populations through Kiva. Bai Tushum & Partners ia a leading microfainance organization in Kyrgyzstan. Bai Tushum & Partners is a reliable financial partner which contributes to the economic growth of the Republic ofKyrgyzstan by providing affordable microfinance services in rural areas as well as in cities, thus helping  create jobs and serving the interests of its clients of investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Rodovico

texts.en:
Rodovico is married with five children. He is 67 years old and lives in Villa Consuelo, Ozamis City.

Rodovico sells a variety of products, including shampoo, soap and toothpaste, to earn a living.  He has had this business for 10 years. Each month, he earns Php 8,000 doing this type of work. He has requested a loan of 40,000 to purchase a bigger variety of products for his retail store.

Rodovico has been a member of PMPC for 4 years.

loans.use: to purchase products such as shampoo, toothpaste, and soap for his retail store.

loans.name: Aida's Group

texts.en:
Aida, 21, is the leader of this group. She is married and has a young son. In 2008 she started a cattle breeding business with the purchase of a calf. With the generated revenue she has purchased furniture for her house. She plans to do further work in this business and therefore needs to broaden it. The purpose of the loan is to purchase additional heads of cattle. Aida’s dream is to purchase her own house. 

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en: Merlyn is 36 years old and lives in Malintuboan, Labason. She is married with four children. Merlyn works in the fish industry and sells fish for a living. She has been doing this for 20 years. She has requested a loan to purchase more fish to sell. Merlyn has been a member of Kiva partner, PMPC, for one year.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Gulzamira's Group

texts.en:
Gulzamira, 54, is the leader of this group. She is a widow with a grown-up child and resides in the town of Tashkomur. Gulzamira’s business is livestock breeding and reselling. She has been doing this since 1984, when she and her husband bought four sheep and five goats. Since then she has made a monthly income of 6,000 KGS, which has helped to finish the construction of her kitchen. Her initial capital was only 900 KGS. The purpose of this loan is to purchase feed for livestock and two more goats.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase goats and feed for livestock.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 46-year-old lady, married to Zainal, who is a 56-year-old man. They are blessed with ten children, namely: Faisal and Fahnan, both of whom are married; Farid, who is graduated from senior high school; Fajrin, who is working in a private company; Adi, who is working in Jakarta; Fahrul, who is in the third level of senior high school; Fadly, who is in the second level of junior high school; and Fauziah, Fikri and Fadillah, who are still in elementary school.

Fatima has a food stall business. She has been engaged with this business for three years. Prior to running the food stall business, Fatima used to run a kitchen equipment business. She ran her business door to door. One day, she decided to stop that business and initiated a food stall business. Fatima loves her current business because she feels that the food stall business helps her in generating income quicker than her previous business. Moreover, currently she has many customers who always come to buy food from her. Fatima employs two workers to help her in serving the customers.  

Fatima and her husband are aware that they are still responsible for financing six children, both in education as well as their living needs. Fatima desires to improve her business by adding more items and to sell, for example, various cakes and beverages. Fatima thinks that the more options of food that she offers, the more customers would like to come to her food stall.  Fatima also wants to buy a motorbike in installments to help her in buying foodstuff at the market. Therefore, Fatima is requesting a loan amounting to 10,000,000 IDR from TLM. She is hoping that TLM will assist her in making her dreams come true.

loans.use: to purchase foodstuff and a motorbike in installments.

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
Maribeth is married with five children. She is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines.

She is a farmer and grows rubber trees to earn a living. She has been doing this for five years. She has requested a loan to redeem her land for her plantation of rubber trees.

Maribeth has been a member of PMPC for one year.

loans.use: to redeem her land for her plantation of rubber trees.

location.town: Talinga, Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Asilkan's Group

texts.en:
Asilkan, 46, is the leader of this group. She is a widow with three kids and resides in the small coal mining town of Tashkomur. Her son is in the army while her daughters go to school and help Asilkan with running her business. She has been involved in livestock breeding and the selling of dried fruits for twenty years. She has been running these two businesses successfully, generating a monthly income of about $140. The purpose of the loan is the purchase of more livestock for further fattening and reselling. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more salt, sodas, soap, cosmetics, sugar, fine flour and so on for his retail shop.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a married man with five children, three of whom still attend school, while two have graduated from school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past eight years, he has operated a retail shop business, selling to his neighbors. Ali faces the major challenges of the high cost of transportation in his business and also seasonality, because during the rainy season it becomes difficult to operate his business. Ali dreams of expanding his business to a wholesale shop in the future.
